div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette THE ENGLISH DAILY NEWSPAPER. ESTABLISHED 1880. Editor and Manager - - R. SHELLAC Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 15, loot.
div.p: "THE DECLINE OF GERMANY
rim phrasemay seem to some of us extremely

inappropriate ; for it is on the ascent, the expansion, the increase of Germany that Englishmen have been invited to concentrate their attention. To many of uk modern Germany figures as the embodiment of successful ambitions ; our Teutophobes dislike the Father - land because of its remorseless determine to achieve greatness and its steady, persistent unflinching devotion to that object. They contrast the energy of the Germans with our own slackness ; their scientific organisation..,: industry and commerce with our haphazard individualism : the resolution with which .Germany is strengthening her armamen with the indifference exhibited in Englan; tdwards the reduction of the Army and thf; weakening of the first-line Navy. We pay Germany the compliment of being a little afraid of her ; hut it does not occur to us that she stands in any need of our pr- We note the advance of the Teutonic Pow* during the forty years which have elapsed since Pi ussia suddenly strode armry into the rin^ to humble Austria, and n-e ask apprehensively where it will end.

Yet here are some of the most influential exponents of public opinion telling us,says the "Evening Standard and St. James's Gazette, that it has ended already. The words we have quoted arc from the "Frankfurter Zeitung, an advanced Liberal organ, but one of the ablest » and most influential political journals in Continental Europe. It exhorts all true patriots to prepare seriously for the next elections to the Reichstag, and "to train the people to exercise independence and insight, in order that the decline of Germany which has set in may be arrested." Here is an example of that "prevailing pessimism" which this same Frankfort newpaper and other observers declare to be far too widely spread to be dissipated by a Voice from the Throne. Kaiser William may have "no use" for the doubters, but they go on with their "obstinate questionings" all the same. They see many reasons for believing, with all her soldiers, and ships, and cartels, and moneyed men, that she Is not nearly so strong and safe as she appears to those who only consider her from the outside.

In the first place, her political situation causes anxiety. The revelations of the Hohen- lohe Memoirs are disturbing. From them we discover that the supreme Government of the Empire is a nest of intrigue and personal ambition, rife with slander, falsehood, and duplicity of all kinds. It is not the Parliament that rules Germany, nor the Imperial Chancellor, nor the Ministers, nor even the Emperor: but apparently obscure and transient knots of Court favourites working through members of the Royal Family, ladies connected with the Household, Palace Chamberlains, and the like.

We are back in the France of Louis XV. almost in the Russia of Catherine II. Vet Germany is a country under a nominal constitutional regime, with something like manhood suffrage, and several millions of electors always prepared to vote for the Socialists ! To intrigue seems to be added something uncommonly like corruption. There is a "crisis"understood to be in full swing just now, though it works characteristically below the surface. General von Po</- bielski, one of the Kaiser's confidants and Minister of Agriculture, was accused, and was apparently unable to refute the. accusation, of having made profits through his connection with a firm of Government contractors. The Chancellor and public opinion called upon him to resign ; and he did so.
Rut the Chancellor has other difficulties.

His policy is not endorsed by anv genuine Parliimentary majority ; the economic situation is bad, and much social distress is caused by the cost of food, which is artificially kep: up to satisfy the agrarians. All this cannot but help the Socialists, who are likely to make further additions to their numbers at the next elections. The day may even be approach- . ng when the Social Democrats may cOrne in * with a majority equal to all the other parties combined. (This would lx* "crisis indeed ; since it would be necessary to keep the administration working, under Parliamentary forni<. with a. majority that could, and certainly ^ would, not be.permitted the smallest share of the. responsibilities of office. To give power to the Socialists would approach perilously near to revolution : to refuse it to them, after they had "snowed under" all their rivals, might mean the dbnyersioh of the present ^yeiled^ absolutism into an open Autocracy. These are the difficulties at home ; and whenever thoughtful Germans look abroad they see further embarrassments in prospect. France, England, Russia, aro getting to a good understanding : Austria is becoming more doubtful as an ally, as the Balkan States are drawing closer together. Germany feels herself isolated, and all her angry struggles to release herself from the position only expose her to further suspicions. We do not agree with the Frankfort journal that Germany is on the down grade, nor is it any desire of ours that she should "decline." But we can understand why many of her own citizens are restless and dissatisfied.

div.p: In Cairo, on Tuesday, a native mason em- ; ployed on a building in oourse of erection in Kasr-el Aini-street, was killed by a beam weighing 50 kilograms, which fell from an upper storey on to his head.

div.head: Burried Alive.
div.p: In Cairo, on Mooday, in the Honcïly quarter, a native woman and her child were crushed to death beneath the rains of a cei'iog which gave way. The father of the family had a narrow escape.

div.head: Anniversary.
div.p: To day being the anniversary c-f the proclamation of the Brazilian Ripublic, a reception t was held at the Brazilian Consulate this morning by Count Debbane, who also exchanged official visits with H. E. the Governor of Alexandria and the other members of the local Consular Corps.

div.head: Suez Canal.
div.p: On the 13th November, 11 vesselp, 4 northward and 7 southward bound, transited the Canal, and paid transit and passenger toll Fr. 227,713 22. Of these vessels, 3 were British, 2 German, 1 Italian, 2 Dutch, 1 French, 1 Norwegian, and 1 Austrian. The total revenue since November 1 is Fr. 3,232,613.63. Poring this period, 126 vessels transited the Canal, 60 northward and 66 southward bound.

div.p: M. Raoul Ponoet, lessee of the Khédivial Opera House, and some of the members of the opera company have arrived at Cairo. The remainder are expected on Snnday and Tuesday next. The first opera of the season at the Khédivial Theatre, "William Tell," is billed for the 26th It was last acted on the same stage five years ago. M. Esoalais, tenor, and Mlle Charpentier will make their débat in the pieoe.

div.head: Cairo British Consulate Evacuated.
div.p: Owiog to the extraordinary bad smells arising apparently from the. aooumulation of sewage and to the bursting of varioas drainpipes, it has been found necessary to evacaate H.B.M.'s Consulate at Cairo. We learn that the home authorities have been communicated with with a view to obtaining temporary premises in which the consalar work can be carried on, pending the construction of a new Consulate on the site acquired more than two years ago by the British Government, on which np to the present not a stone has been laid.

div.head: Hamburg-America Line.
div.p: The German steamship Habsbnrg(6,500 tons) is j oat ont on her maidea voyage from Europe. She is the pioneer boat of the new monthly service which this enterprising company has inaugurated between Hamburg. Lisbon, and the Far East. The steamers which are to run on this line are of the most modern type and have splendid accommodation for paesergers. Sailing from Lisbon on the 25th of every month the steamers will call at Naples first, and from there viâ the nsnal ports to China aud Japan. The establishment of this new line offers special advantage to thoie firms importing wine, fish, fruits, preserves, and other commodities from Portugal and Spain. It will also serve to stimulate and improve the trade between these countries and the East generally.

div.head: Native Jack of all Tracies.
div.p: Mashallah I MashaUah ! Oidy yesterday the Government exptlled the oot-of-work, witness onr excellent Berberin ! But what happiness for Egypt of to-day when many are taking up more than one profession ! It is clear that our proverb, "Seven trades, and no lock," must be exaggerated, and all the more so as it only applies to thoFe who work at a double or at most a triple profession and whose occupations are similar. But while I sought to disprove our proverb,my lucky star led me to the shop of a very active and intelligent native trader. He has seven professions, every one different. He keeps a cefé and a barber's shor, changes your money, and sells you groceries. He is also a musician and a tobacco merchant !. But that makes only six trades, you will say. Surely my intelligent readers have gnessed No. 7 ? He is also—a broker ! f"Al WataD.")

div.head: GERMANY'S FOREIGN RELATIONS
HER INCREASING ISOLATION. GREAT BRITAIN IN EGYPT
div.p: Berlin, November 14.

In the Reichstag, Prince von Bnlow, replying to an interpellation with reference to the in- creasing isolation ot Germany, pointed oat that a Franco German allianoe was beyond realization in view of the feeling in France and the memories of the past, but the Morocco incident thowed that the two nations desired to live in peace. Germany had no idea of openly or seoret'y undermining the relations between Franco and Russia, or France and Great Britain. The Franoo-Rnssian alliance had shown itself to be no danger to peace, and he hoped to be able to say the same for the Franoo- British entente.

Good Russo-German relations had been unimpaired by the Franco-Rossian alliance, and good Anglo-German relations were equally compatible with the "entente oordiale" if the aims of the latter were peacefol. No profound political differences existed between Great Britain and Germany. There had been moments of discord for which both countries were blameable, but no hostile acts had taken place.

He dwelt on the economic interdependence of the two conntrips and repudiated emphatically the idea that Germany was attempting to rival Great Britain's naval power, but it was her duty, he said, to have her fleet commensurate with her oommerce and oversea interests.

He quoted Germany's abstension from obstructing Great Britain in Egypt as an example of her unreserved recognition of Great Britain's position in the world. The establishment of friendly relations wonld require time and patience, owing to a long period of misunderstandings.

Too much importance had been attributed to the alleged personal differences between King Edward and tho Emperor. Neither allow their personal susceptibilities to affeot national interests, ar d the meeting at Kronberg had strengthened the peisonal relations existing between them. (Reuter)

In the Reichstag, Prince von Bulow made statement of the policy of the Empire. Ho said that Frenoh patriotism prevents a dose entente between France and Germany. The Franco-Russian and Anglo-French unions are not dangerous. Germany is developing the advantages of the Triple Alliance. The world policy of Germany does not threaten anybody, but it most be ready for any eventuality. She has never hampered British policy in Egypt.
( Havas)

div.head: LAUNCH OF THE AMERICA.
div.p: At 4 p.m. yesterday the new steamer America, of the Express Nile Steamers Company, was launched at Bahr el Aama, Ghizeh. This fine vessel is 150 feet in length, with a beam of 26 feet, and draws two feet of water. She is triple decked, and the cabins, arranged in the best situations on each deck, hold 54 first class passengers. In the bows is a spacious saloon with large glass windows and an excellent system ot heating by pipes which wi 1 enable passengers to enjoy the view without being in any way incommoded by wind or cold. Another saloon, a smoking room, and a large and comfortable dining saloon complete the installation, which is calculated to give tourists a maximum of comfort. All heating in the saloons, etc., is obtained by ste^m.

The speed of the America is 14 miles per hour,the engines working up to 400 I H.P. The cabins are delightfully got up with telephones, ventilating fans, electric bells, and heaters. The installation for a complete supply of hot and cold water is q îite perfect, and, in a word, passengers on board the America should have a most luxurious journey up the river.
Miss Bessie W. Ems, daughter of the direc tor general of the Express Nile Steamers Co., gracefully baptised the new steamer amid the good wishes of many friends.
The America leaves for her first trip on December 29, starting from Kasr el Nil Bridge at.10 a.m.

div.head: EGYPT IN PARLIAMENT
POWERS AND CAPITULATIONS. NILE MUD WASTE.
div.p: IntheHousa of Commons last Thursday, Mr. J. M. Robertson asked the Secretary of State for Foreign A flairs whether farther action had been taken by the Egyptian Government in sequence to the pircalar which,as Lord Cromer stated in his annual report for 1905, page ?,wa8 addressed to the Powers suggesting, in anticipation of a renewal in February,1905, of the functions of the Mixed Tribanals in Egypt, certain reforms in the working of the Egyptian Capitolations ; and whether he wonld lay npon the table of the House oopies of the replies received to that circular, and other information showing the present state of the negotiations.

Sir E. Grey.— The circular to which the hon. member alludes invited the Powers to take part in an International Commission to consider the question of making certain changes in the law and pr icedare of the Mixed Courts. The assent of all the Powers having been obtained, the Commission oommenced their deliberations, with the result that in March last five draft laws applicable to foreigners, which had been drawn up by the Commission, were submitted to his Majesty's Goveromeut for their approval. His Majesty's Government notified their approval to the Government of Egypt in April, bat I have Dot yet been informed whether the approval of all the other Powers has been obtained. The only correspondence of which his M-jesty's Government have cognisance is that between them and the Government of Euypt, the purport of which I have already notified above. The replies of the other Powers will doabtless be dealt with in Lord Cromer's annoal report, which will in doe coarse be laid before the House ; the matter does not appear to his Majesty's Government to be of sufficient urgency to warrant the immediate publication of separate papers.

Mr. J. M. Robertson asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether, having regard to the fact that of the 50,000,000 tons of Nile mad which pass throngh the Assouan dam annually it was estimated that 30/ 00,000 ton s were lost in the sea, while only 20,000,000 tons were utilized as manure, he would advise the Egyptian Government to adopt measures whereby such a large amount of waste might in fntnre be prevented.

Sir E. Grey.— The Egyptian Government are folly aware of the importance of utilizing the Nile flood to its fullest extent, aud large sums are yearly spent in improving the irrigation system of the oonntry. Irrigation has made very great progress in the last few years, and the progress will be continoed, hot it mast be gradual.

div.head: NEW NATIONALIST ORGAN
div.p: "THE EGYPTIAN STANDARD."

Mustapha Pa-ha Kamel has taken the first step towards fulfilling his promise to provide the Egypt'an pnblio with a daily newspaper promulgating the ideas of the Nationalist Party. A company, of which the "patriot" is chairman, has bean formed with a capital of L.E. 20,000, the object of which is, in the words of the prospectus,"to publish a political, moral, and economical newspaper in the Frenoh and English languages under the names of "L'Etendard Egyptien" and "The Egyptian Standard." The shareholders of the company met at the offices of "El Lewa" in Cairo on Monday and unanimously elected Mustapha Pasha Kamel editor and manager of the new publication.

To quote " El Lewa " : — The aims of this paper will be to defend the rights of Egypt and the Egyptians ; to olaim her independence in accordance with the firmans of the Saltan and the treaties of the Powers ; to demand a Constitution on the lines of other prosperous and civilised countries ; to reveal the oorropt and auworthy acts cf those in authority aud of the people ; to deny any fiotional charge brought against the Egyptian people ; to uphold the principles of justice and freedom ; to eradicate any misunderstanding existing between the Datives and foreigners living in this conntry ; to strengthen friendly relations among them ; to sapport the weak and the oppressed of any nationality or religion."

We have commented on this project of Egypt's self-styled nationalist leader on several occasion and we refrain from farther comment nutil more complete details of the constitution of the company are divalged. It; will be most interesting to as to learn the names of those who have associated themselves with Mustapha Pasha Kamel, by subscribing the capital necessary for the floating of the new journal.

div.head: THE LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL
div.p: Aly Pasha Shirawi, of Minieb, and Maftah Bey Maahad, of Fayoam, have been appointed permanent members of the Legislative Coanoil in plaoe of the late Sheikh Mohamed Abdou and Sheikh Abdel Khalik El-Sadat.

"Al Moayad," commenting 6n the news, approves the appointment of the former bat greatly deprecates that of the latter. * The Government," "Al Moayad" says, "will do no good either to the nation or to itself by overlooking many able and experienced men, and appointing Muftah Bey as permanent member of the Legislative Council merely ^because he is personally known to Lord Cromer, who addressed him as 'friend' last year wjjen his lordship delivered his famous speech at Fayoom."

div.head: PLAGUE AT BEYROUT
THE FIRST CASES
div.p: Beyrout, November 13.

On Thursday last, a suspected case of plsgne was discovered in Haret Hereik, a village of the Lebanon on the southern outskirts of Beyroat. The case ended fatally, and the postmortem examination having apparently confirmed the symptomatic diagnosis a cordon was formed around the hoase of the plagae- stricken man.

Another case has been reported in Rhs Beyroat, bat the patient is said to be on the way to reoovery. In the meantime the Board of Health at Constantinople has telegraphed the Sanitary Office here ordering the observance of a medioal visit against all arrivals from Beyroat.
SERIOUS OUTBREAK OF FIRE.

A little before midnight on Saturday last a fire broke ont in the pharmaceutioal laboratory of Messrs. P. Guigues and Co. This laboratory lies in a Moslem quarter, aud for some years past the inhabitants have been giving signs of serions dissatisfaction with the presence in their midst of an establishment which annoyed them materially by its offensive smoke, and 1 religiously by the existence of large quantities of alcohol, which they considered as a sacrilege and an insult. Despite the many attempts at boycotting made by a truculent party in the qaarter Mr. Gaigues was ill-advised enoogb not to remove to another qaarter where he was less likely to be molested and annoyed.

The faot of the fire having taken place on a Saturday, when the laboratory is washed, and work is suspended and no fires lighted, points to the evidence of incendiarism. Just a month ago Mr. Guignes had been negotiating with a fire insurance oompany, bat the latter having demanded an extra premium owing to the presence cf ethers and alcohols, and further laid down special conditions with regard to the storing separately of such inflammable materials, the negotiations ended in nothing, and the risks remained still anoovered. The loss to Mr. Guignes is estimated at aboot frs. 100,000.

Despite its handsome revenae our Municipality does not possess any pomps nor anything approaching the organization of a fire brigade, and the flames had to be extinguished by the employment of primitive means. Most fortunately they did not attain the part where the large quantities of ethers and alcohols lay, otherwise the whole quarter might have been jeopardized.

div.head: CRUELTY TO ANIMALS
THE LANDING OF CATTLE.
div.p: Our attention has once more been drawn to the crnel manner in which cattle arriving at Alexandria harhonr are disembarked, and we do not hesitate to orge the Society for the Prevention of Crnelty to Animals to establish for themselves the troth of the details related to ns, and, if they satisfy themselves that the charge of oroelty is well founded, to take vigorous action to put a stop to it.

We are glad to say that in the execution of the admirable work which the S.P.C.A. have undertaken they receive the full support and co-operation ot the Mixed Tribanals in those cases in which they deem it necessary to prosecute, and we have, therefore, every hope that when the society takes this matter op they will be speedily enabled to remove all cause for complaint.

We need hardly remind our readers that the Quarantine Board have quite recently completed a magnificent quay for the embarkmeDt and disembarkment of cattle with suitable sheds at an expense of some L.E. 200,000. Formerly it was necessary for cattle to be disembarked into lighters aod pat ashore from these, bat now they can be driven from the deck of the ship on to the quay direct. The animals, however, are packed in the holds of the ships and for the purpose of raising them to the deck the shipping agents have supplied belly-bands. According to onr iL formant these are by no means always oted, and it is a common practice to rope the cattle by the horns and hanl them on to the deck in this maDDer. Here, however, the cruelty dues not cease. Theanimal8 might be quietly driven on to the quay, but in order to expedite matters the cattle drovers are accastomed to bind three or f >ar together by the horns and drag them ashore. In this way the cattle suffer a great deal of unnecessary pain aud in very many instances their horon are broken.

Onr informant remarked that in the time of the late M. A. Vacari, for some time chiei inspector of the S.P.C.A., these brotal practices were not allowed, and ha is inclined to blame the inspeotors of the S.P.C.A. for iadifferenoe. Whatever justice there may be in such an accusation we ate assured that by thos drawing the attention of the committee of the society to the state of affairs whatever cruelty exists wilf be dealt with satisfactorily. Let ns also point ont to the shipping agents the necessity for insisting npon the belly bands, which they have provided in order to avoid cruelty, being ased in every caee.

div.head: DUKE OF CONNAUGHT'S TOUR.
div.p: The "Express" is informed that the Dake ot Connaught will start lor the East next month on an official toor as Inspector-General of the Forces. It is understood that he will visit, among other places, Ceylon, Horg Kong, and Singapore. His Royal Highness will then pay a visit to India. This, of course, will be unofficial.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE
"LE DEMI_MONDE"
div.p: To adequately appreciate this play, it is to be borne in mind that Dumas, in inventing that very useful and significant word whence the pieue derives its title, was far from wishing it to convey the meaning now usually attached to it. As he himself points out, the Demimonde implies not the common crowd ot profligates, but the class of déclaspées, who, though originally of the "vrai monde," have either left it or been ejected throngh transgression of its conventions. In the play given last night, types of such déclassées are exhibited in Mme de Santis, a "divorce oourt widow," and in Mme de Vernières.a real widow with a real dead hasband, of which consommation she is jastly proad. With her lives a niece, Marcelle, who, though in the demi monde, is yet not of it, her great desire being in faot to rise oat of her surroundings by aDy honest means. Respectability at all costa is also the sole aspiration of the heroine. Suzanne, Baronne d'Anges. She, unlike the others, is not a déclassée, but on the ooDtrary is of low origin and had hitherto regarded the demimonde as the summum bonum. Once, however, her position there established, her am-bitou, which will do nothing by halves, drives her to attempt submission into the real world. This can only be obtained by a respectable right-hand marriage, an opporunity for which, Suzanne thinks, is admiraly provided in M. de Nanjac, an officer on leave after 10 years absence, who thus knows nothing of her past.He is violently in love with her, and all wonld go well were it not for the vigorous opposition of Olivier de Jalin, with whom she was formerly in liaison. Olivier strikes up & warm, if eadden, friendship for de Nanjac, and henceförward considers it his daty to warn him of Suzanne's! reputation by every means he can resort to, save that of divalging the place he once 0ocapied in her affections. His devices to! enlighten the somewhat dense bat inflammatory officer are equalled only by the almost saperhuman talent Suzanne displays in thwarting them by sham proofs of all kinds. At! length she is forced into trath, the very confession of which she adroitly employs to increase Nadjac's ardour. Meanwhile, Jalip's notions of i bonour onlminate in a dnel with Nadjac being

thrust apon him. He makes this the means of finally convincing his friend and exposing Suzanne. He himself ends by marrying MarI celle, well satisfied no doubt with his rather exaggerated sense of daty.

On the whole the play is certainly not thrilling, while the constant schemes and counter-ecbemes render it more confusiog than interesting. It is worth while comparing the similar ambitions of Sazsode and Marcelle to mark the respective failure and success, dae mainly to the one being the unlucky possessor of a past and present, from which the other's youth and strength of mind preserve her. Damas seems to lay far more stress on a woman's past than on her fature and, despite the ansavoury schemes Suzanne employs to gaic her end, her charm, tact, and braids would serve her well in a respectable milien. Since failore attends her, we will not here enter into discussion as to what joy or happiness such a nature would find in conventional respectability.

To say that Mme Hading took the part of Suzanne is simply to say that it was perfectly interpreted. The great actress maintained, save for one ontbarst, & wonderfal restraint. By the facial expression alone one could read the tense ambition, the momentary triomph and the anguish of failare, bat no faltering of voice or attitude b3trayed her desigos, antil the tower of lies and shifts fell with & crash at the end of Act IV. As Olivier de Jalin, M. Arnaud acted with mach suavity and ease and, in fact, did well with a remunerative part. M. Hauterive w48 satisfactory as de Nunjac, I as was Mlle MacLeane as Marcelle.
The house was again thin, which is as regrettable as it is surprising.
Mme Hading has decided to give two extra reprezentations in Alexandris, namely on Sa tarday and Sunday, before leaving for Cairo. The plays for these two occasions have not yet been selected.

div.head: OVATION FOR M. SAINT-SAENS.
div.p: The "New York Herald" says that M. Camille Saint Saëns' reception apon the occasion of his first American appearance at Carnegie Hall,, New York, made the sturdy old veteran of three ecore and ten as happy as a schoolboy. The audience was as brilliant 88 at the Metropolitan on an opera night, and when he appeared the entire gathering rose and thundered & welcome which drowned the orchestra's fanfare.

The old man was kept standing bowing and smiling several minutes while the extraordinary scene continued. Then he sat down at the piano, and, with the New York Symphony Orchestra, under Mr. Walter Damrosch, played his "Africa Fantasie." The entire programme was quite an ovation.

div.head: AN EGYPTIAN PRIEST'S TOMB.
div.p: Mons. A. Barsanti, while making researches for the Service des Antiquitér, has discovered an interesting tomb of the fifth centary B.cat) the back of the Pyramid of Unas. The tomb, which belonged to a priest named Hekanem. saf, proved to bave been intaot. On being opened, a large number of funeral stataettes in blue enamel were found near the door, together with a hundred blue glazed bowls of an unknowo age.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Kamel Pasba and Princess Nazli Fazel Hanem arrived h-re this morning from Earope.
The Dowager Lady Ashbarton, who will be accompanied by the Hon. Gay and Mrs. Baring, and the Hon. Alexander Baring, is coming out co Egypt early in December.
Boghos Pasha Nubar has returned to Cairo From Earopo accompanied by his family.
M. Pranièros, President of the Mixed Coart of 1st Instance, Cairo, has retarned to the Capital from Europe. -
Chitty Bey will take op his pew fanctions in the Ministry of Finance at the beginping of December. We learn that the title to be borne by his new appointment has not yet been definitely decided.

Professor Alphonse Mariette, who died recently at the ripe age of 80, was a brother of the late Mariette Pasha, the Egyptologist, well-known to archæɔlogists as a pioneer. Profes sor Mariette was known in the literary world for bis originality of thought. He was honoured by the King by being appointed French tator to the late Dake of Clarence and to the present Prince of Wales. Later he was instractor to the Princess of Wales, the Princess May of Teck. Daricg the last 20 years he lived (the Times" states) in retirement at Raeil, near Paris. English in his sympathies and manner, but loyally French at heart, M. Mariette always aimed at fostering that good feeling between the two countries which now at last seems to be firmly established

M-jor General Henry Hallam Parr, C.B., C.M.G, whose name has been on the active list of the Army for over forty years, is to retire within a few days. Joining the 13th Foot (now the Somersetshire Light Lifantry) 88 an ensign in 1865, he was raised to the rank of lieutenant-colonel after less than twenty years' service, and became major-general in 1899. His first campaigning experience was passed in the Kaffir war of 1877, and he afterwards acted as military secretary to Sir Bartle Frere when Governor of the Cape. On the ontbreak of the Arabi Pasha rebellion, MajorGeneral Parr was appointed commander of mounted infantry, but was, unfortunately, severely wounded at Tel-el-Mahata ; but in the Nile expedition, which closely followed, he organised a carrier corps, and acted &8 commandant at Saakin, taking part in the battle of Tamai and the advance on Tamanieh. He was created a C.B. in 1893, and from 1895-8 held the position of Iospector General of Ord. nance at the War Office, subsequently holding command of the troops at Shorncliffe and in the North Western District.

M.M. 8. S. Congo on Taesday last, was Mr. Sidney Jennings, a director of the well-known firm of "George Jennings" of London (sanitary engineers), who is visiting Egypt on business in connection with important work in this country. Mr. Jennings, who will subsequently proceed to Constantinople, leaves to morrow for Cairo, where he proposes staying at the Villa Victoria.
The King of Greece bas' conferred the 3rd class of the Order of the Savioar on Khalil Bey Shahin.

div.head: SHRAGER BROTHERS' FAILURE.
div.p: In the Court of Bankruptcy last week the case of Shrager Brother2-3x parte Cecil Shrager came before Mr. Registrar Linplater.

This was an application for an order of discharge by Mr. Cecil Shrager, a partner in the firm of Shrager Brothers, merchants, 4, Lloyd's-avenue, London, and of Calcatta, Co. lombo, Singapore, Alexandria, and Broome, Western Australia. The trastee estimated the liabilities of the firm at £153,252 10s. 7d., the assets at £15,533 138. 2d., and the dividend payable to creditors at not more than 28. in the pound. It appeared that the Official Rg. ceiver, Mr. E. S. Grey, was not yet in po88e8sion of sufficient information to enable him to report fully on the affairs of the applicant, and the application accordingly stood over.
Mr. Edward Clayton appeared for the trastee.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Portugal arrived at Marseilles from Alexandria yester. day morning.
The Ellerman liner Egyptian ssiled hence last evening for Liverpool direct with a fall cargo, including 4,984 bales of cotton.
The Papayanni liner Algerian left Malta last night and is expected to arrive here on the 18th inst. with passengers and mails.

FIGHT WITH THE POLICE. TWO MORE BANDS FORMED.

div.p: The Ferreira raid is not considered Lere as a political affair demanding the attention cf the diplomatic organs. It is looked upon mere ly ss a small band which has no political aim.
The police will assist the British forces in the mea8are8 taken by them for the pursuit and arrest of thB band iu case it should cross tin frontier into German territory.(Reuter)
A detachment cf police had a half boors fight with Ferreira's raiders 14 miles to the east tf Upington. The raiders letroated into the bush. Two more bands bave eutered Cape Colony. (Reuter)

div.head:
KING HAAKON IN ENGLAND.
LUNCHEON AT GUILDHALL.

div.p: A chapter of the Knights of the Garter has been held at Windsor in great state. King i Haakon wasinvf sted with the Order. (Reuter)
Later.

King Haakon and Queen Maud, accom panied I y the Prince and Princess of Wales and the Doke and Dnchess of Connaoght, were entertained at loncheon in the Guildhall. There was a most distinguished assemblage of Cabinet Ministers, ex-Cabinet Ministers, and Peers. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE EDUCATION BILL.
THE LORDS' AMENDMENTS.

div.p: Mr. Birrel), speaking at Bristol, said that the Education Bill, as altered by the House of Lords, was a sheer impossibility. He hoped that in the report stage the Lords woald recognise that they had gone too far. If they did not, the Liberal administration was an imposture and a sham unless the constitution was changed. (Teuter)

div.head:
THE PORTSMOUTH RIOTERS.
COURT-MARTIAL FOR RINGLEADERS

div.p: Eleven ringleaders in the Portsmouth riots are to be court-martialled. A court ot enquiry will inve'tigate the allegation that Lieutenant Collard had improperly ordered the men to kneel. (Reuter)
The new War Office in Whitehall was opened yesterday. ( T euter)

div.head:
THE KBRBELA DISTURBANCES.
TURCO PERSIAN COMMISSION.

div.p: Owing to the disturl accès at Keibela, the Persian Ambassador has proposed to the Porte the appointment of a Turco Persian commission of enquiry. {Reuter)

div.head:
M. CLEMENCEAU S POLICY.
VOTE OF CONFIDENCE.

div.p: The extreme Radicals have violently attacked M. Clemenceau's milder temporizing policy towards the Church.
The Chamber cf Deputies has voted confidence in the Government by 416 votes to 163.
(Reuter)

div.head: THE MEMOIRS OF JOINVILLE
div.p: JoinvilV.s Memoirs differ from the nsnal ruu of med ieval chronicles in one very important point. He Lis a hefo. The character of Lonis IX. stands out from his pages with extraordinary vividness ; surrounded by heroes, there can bo no donbt that the King himself was the greatest character of all. Not that Joinville describes his sainted master with any courtly flattery, or with the "extravagant eulogy" of other writers on the subject. He i« not afraid to mention the King's tempers and orldit:es, or to sympathie with the Qoeen, who sometimes found her truly Royal hosband somfwhat trying in daily life. Bnt in a series of wonderfully vivid pictures be Rets St. Loais before us as a real Christian and a man of quite extraordinary nobility of natnre ; a typical figure, it ja trne, of the best side of the Middle Ages, and yet anentirely human and liv rg creature who might belong to our own day, and whose virtoes of unselfishness, justice, generosity, loftine-s of mind, are just as rare and as admirable now as they were then.

Tea story of the Crusade is well known : how the King and his followers sailed from Marsedles, singing Vent Creator Spiri'us : how thry arrived iu Cyprus, where King Lonis received messengers from the King of the Tartars, and sent him in retnrn a tent of scarlet cloth made like a chapel, with pictures from the Creel, "to entice them into onr faith how they sailed to E?ypt, and found a Saracen for» e awaiting them, which fled, so that they took possession of Damietta : then the march on Caire, and the wonderfnl description of the Nile, "that river which flows out of the Earthly Paradise," and spreads itself in 83ven streams over Egypt : —

"Before the river reaches Egypt, men who are practised in it cast their nets loose into the stream at nightfall, and when morning comes, they find in their nets snoh raw goods as ar9 imported into this country ; to wit, ginger, rhubarb, aloes and cinnamon. And it is said, that these things are washed down from the E*rtlry Paralise ; that the wind blows down the tree of Eieu just as the wind in this oonntry blows down the dry wood ; and that wbat merchants sell to os iu this country, is the diy wood that falls into the river there."

There was search made in those days for the sources of the Nile. The Sultan's. men, according to Joinville, went as far as a great wall of rook over which the river fell, and where they saw "marvellous strange wild beasts of various kinds, lions and serpents and elephants, that came and gszod at them from the water below, as they went climbing upwards along the river bank."

The description of the long river fight with the Siracens which led up to the battle of Mansourah is an interesting lesson in mediaeval warfare ; and the account wh;ch follows it of the terrible sufferings of the Crusading army, with their full surrender to the Saracens, is fnll of extraordiuary details which bring the whole series of frightful scenes before our eyes. It. is full, too, of characteristic touches of nature : there is a certain pagan chivalry minglid with the cruelty of the Sultan and his Emirs. After the murder ol the Saltan by his own people, it is carious to read that the Emirs talked of making the oaptive King ot Franca Sultan of Egypt, so much had his greatness impressed them. And Louis told Joinville himself that "he would most certainly not have refused it." They were only hindered, Joinville says, by the determined nature i f the King's Christianity. They feared that "if this nation were to make him their Sultan, they would either have to torn Christians or he would put them all to death."

The King and his army were allowed to leave Egypt on payment of a ransom cf two hundred thousand pounds' weight of gold, his brother, the Cjunt of Poitiers, being kept as a hott-ige till the money was paid. It was collected slowly and with difficulty, and some were doubtful of the Count's safety

There were some among the Coancil who would have dismaded the King from paying over the money nntil he should have bis brother back. But the King replied, that he should pay it over, for it was in his agreement; and let them in return keep their part of the baTgain, if they were honestly minded. Then Lord Philip of Annemoes (Nemours?) told the King, that they had done the Saracens ont of a ten thousand ponndsr weight, whereupon the King became violently angry, and said that he insisted on the ten thousand pounds being restored to them, since he had agreed to pay them two hundred thousand pounds before leaving the river. Then I trod od Lord Philip's foot, and told the King not to pay any heed to him, for he was not speaking the truth, for that the Saracens would out-cheat anybody in the world. And Lord Philip said, that what I said was trim, for he had only said it in jest And the King said that: That kind ofje'fc came to grief. 'And I command you,' said the King to Lord Philip, by the faith you owe me, and as n y vassal that yon are. that if those ten thousand pounds have not been paid, you will have them paid. "
* The Memoir* of the Lord of Joinville.A New English Version by Ethel Wedgwood.With illustrations London : John Murray. [l»s. not.]

div.head: PHOTOGRAPHY IN EGYPT
div.p: THE CAUSE OF FOGGING.
Mr. John McDowa'l, F.R C.S , contributes to the "Chemical News" the following interesting article upon the cause of the foggirg of photograph plates in tropical olimates : —

Some time ago, while in Upper Egypt, I had occasion to use a foil plate camera with wooden double dark slides. I found the plates to be nearly always Jogged, notwithstanding the fact that the slides were perfectly light tight and all the ordinary precautions of the dark room were taken.
The fogging sometimes showed itself as an opaque clondirg all over the plate ; sometimes the outline of the woodwork of the slide oonld be seen, and some4imes the grain of the wood
was distinctly visible.

Shortly after I had made these observations, an eclipse of the sun occurred which was total at Assouan, and many scientific men went there to photograph it. On developing their plates, they found that many of them were rendered worthless or their value as a scientific record was greatfy diminished by the same kind of fogging which I have described, and they were at a loss to explain it, although some suggested radio-aotivity as a cause. I have recently investigated this, and herewith give what appears to he the explanation.

I took a quarter plate double dark slide and placed two Special Rapid plates in it. On the one plate I pot a thin piece of tissae paper, in the centre of which I had out out a star-shaped hole ; on the other plate I pat an ordinary glass mioroscopic slide. These objects were inside the slide, and in actual contact with the film. I then placed the double dark slide in a metal box and heated it up to about 40° C., which is the average temperature of Upper Egypt iu the summer time. The slide was placed on a porcelain support in the metal box, which was heated by a lamp.

After heating for fifteen hours I developed the plates, and found them to be very strongly fogged, the film being quite opaque ; but under the place where the thin tissue paper was, and also under where the miorosoopio slide was, there was no fogging. In the centre of the tissue paper I had out a star-shaped ho'e, and on the plate opposite this was a starshaped mark which was quite opaque.
I tried various other objects, and found that they acted in a similar manner.

The faot that the agent which produced the fogging could not penetrate glass or transparent tissae paper shows that it cannot be doe to ethereal vibrations at all of the nature of light. It is doe to vapours which are oocluded in the wood at ordinary temperatures, but which are exhaled when the wood is heated. These vapours, which may be peroxide of hydrogen or volatile organic compounds from the varnish, possess the chemic 1 property of reducing the Balts of silver which are contained in the film, so that on development the plate appears to have been exposed to the light.

I tried another experiment by fixing a piece of brass tubing in a hole ont in the slide and mak'iog the joint light tight, a plate was then put in and the whole heated to 40° C. in the metal box as before.

The brass tube was connected to a water- pump, by which the vapours in the immediate vicinity of the tube were aspirated out. The fogging appeared to be less under the place where the tube was than on any ether part of the plate.

The value cf these experiments to the photographer goiüg abroad is apparent. He shoald get a thin piece of glass or mica with which to cover the plate in the dark slide and protect it from the vapours, and fogging would be entirely prevented by this means.
If the dark slide was opened and heated for some days, there is little donbt hot that the vaponr which causes the fogging would be expelled, and it could then be used with confidence in the tropios.

The simplest method of preventing the fogging is to paste a piece of paper over the inside of the wooden sliding pieces which are pulled out when the piste is about to be exposed, which effectually preveuts the vapour from diffusing out of the wood on to the photographic plate.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: RIFLE SHOOTING.
CAIRO BRITISH RIFLE CLUB.

Ou Friday last the club shot off a match with ihe 2nd Battalion Royal Innifkilling Fusiliers at Tourah. when the latter won by three points. Scoring was low owing to the strong changing wind and detective light towards the end. The chief scores were, for the winners :—
Lieut. Lloyd 29 -f 28 + 33 = 90
S^t. McDonnell 27 -f- 31 -f 30 = 88
Sgt. Dolley 29 + 31 + 28 = 88
and for the lowers
Mr. Craig 28 + 31 -f 29 = 88
Mr. Kearney 28 + 32 + 27 = 87
Mr. Williamson 29 + 29 + 27 = 85
Qn Friday there will be a spoon competi
tion at 200, 500, and 600 yards.
